page.title: 02Sawston Hall
page.content: {Sawston Hall}was originally called Pyratt's Manor. The present building dates from the early 16th century. The 1580 survey mentions two fishponds. The moat on the south side of the wall is fed by springs. There is a mulberry tree in the garden and according to family superstition a death would occur in the Huddleston family if a branch fell off.In the inner courtyard there is an underground well. The garderobe is a first time lavatory. There are three priest holes: one near the garderobe, one near Mary Tudor's bedroom( she slept there in 1553) and the main one in the tower in the courtyard, this being one of the finest in the country. It was sold to the Cambridge School of Languages in 1983.
